results.title: Communist triumph and consolidation, 1945-1971
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, Ken Rosen and Metromedia Producers Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “China: A Century of Revolution”.
Shows how, in four years after Japan’s defeat, the Communists chased the Nationalists off the mainland and established a People’s Republic in Peking. Discusses how the Communists brought a semblance of order to China, despite hostility from Western powers. The other parts of this 3-part series are Part I Agonies of nationalism, 1800-1927 and Part II Enemies within and without, 1927-1944. Narrated by Joseph Campanella.

results.title: Enemies within and without: 1927-1944. - 2nd ed.
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “China: A Century of Revolution”.
Highlights the complex interrelationship of problems in China, including the invasion of Manchuria by Japan and the challenge to the Nationalists by the Communist followers of Mao Tse-tung. Narrated by Jospeh Campanella.

results.title: Agonies of nationalism: 1800 - 1927
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “China: A Century of Revolution”.
Documents invasion by foreign troops, the disappearance of the Manchu Dynasty, eruption of the civil war, rise of the warlords, influence of Sun Yat-sen, Chiang Kai-shek, and the threat of the communists.

group_works.title: The China teapot story: a Chinese legend
group_works.creator_credit: Wladislaw Neherbecki and Sterling Educational Films

results.title: The China teapot story: a Chinese legend
results.creator_credit: Wladislaw Neherbecki and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Folktales from around the world”.
An animated story about a Chinese potter who makes a beautiful porcelain teapot for the Emperor who regards its worth as priceless. It is then seen to be desirable and is inevitably stolen from the Emperor’s palace. In a series of transactions that follow in various parts of the world, it is exchanged for items from other cultures that are equally regarded as priceless. Provides a simple introduction to the notion of trade, as well as the economic and aesthetic considerations involved in the determination of the worth of a product. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

group_works.title: Cultural conflict
group_works.creator_credit: David Zweck and Country Education Project

results.title: Cultural conflict
results.creator_credit: David Zweck and Country Education Project
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English for H.S.C. students”.
A program of interviews and discussions led by Peter Couchman. The texts “Mister Johnson” (Joyce Carey), “The Inheritors” (William Golding), “A Place Apart” (Dervla Murphy) and “The Immigrants” (Wendy Lowenstein and Morag Loh) are considered in examining the causes of cultural conflict, how people are affected by it, how conflict can both enrich and impoverish individuals and communities and how conflict is resolved. Also appearing are Dr. M. McLaughlin and Charles D’Aprano.

results.title: Formal thought
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Piaget’s Developmental Theory”.
Illustrates tasks that challenge the thinking of postprimary school students. Involves proportional reasoning, separation of variables, combinatorial logic and the integration of these in an analysis of a balanced beam with weights. Suitable for tertiary level and teachers.
